comments.author: jduell.mcbugs@gmail.com
comments.creator: jduell.mcbugs@gmail.com
comments.text:
It would be great to be able collect tuples like (load size, load time) in telemetry, so we could (ideally) create charts with item 1 on the X axis and item 2 on the Y axis.

Otherwise, the bet I can do to gather info on how load size affects load time is to create separate histograms like "load_time_1K", "2K", etc.  which is gross.
comments.raw_text:
It would be great to be able collect tuples like (load size, load time) in telemetry, so we could (ideally) create charts with item 1 on the X axis and item 2 on the Y axis.

comments.creator: jduell.mcbugs@gmail.com
comments.author: jduell.mcbugs@gmail.com
comments.raw_text:
Oh, and to follow up on discussion at 

   http://blog.mozilla.com/tglek/2011/06/22/developers-how-to-submit-telemetry-data/

I'd prefer to also have a C++ api for this, not just JS.  We'll want to use in HTTP cache/channels.

comments.author: taras.mozilla@glek.net
comments.creator: taras.mozilla@glek.net
comments.text: I'm not sure if creating separate histograms is such a bad idea. I think the way to do it is to add a histogram recording sizes of network requests, figure out 3-5 important ones and then measure load time on them. Using a graph would provide you with more data, but I'm not sure if having more data is useful in this case.
comments.raw_text: I'm not sure if creating separate histograms is such a bad idea. I think the way to do it is to add a histogram recording sizes of network requests, figure out 3-5 important ones and then measure load time on them. Using a graph would provide you with more data, but I'm not sure if having more data is useful in this case.

comments.text: *** Bug 778122 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

comments.creator: lmandel@mozilla.com
comments.author: lmandel@mozilla.com
comments.text: *** Bug 746321 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

comments.raw_text:
I'm commenting here since Bug 746321 was closed. 

1. Two point histograms (can we call them joint histograms for 2 variables?) is essential if we want to know the how two variables behave together - the solution i've heard is to shoehorn this into 1D histograms (where buckets correspond to cartesian products of each bucket in the respective single distributions and as pointed out comment 1 " ... .  which is gross."

Problem with this is that when Release management or other teams ask us questions "How is Y affected by A and B" we can't answer this question unless some developer has already collected *3 point* histograms for Y,A and B.

2. The way around (1) has been mentioned in the closed bug: collect multiple histograms over smaller time windows for each of Y,A and B so instead of one histogram for Y, A and B sent in a packet, but multiple ones for each - we can then approximate joint behavior.

The current status is : currently Telemetry is not useful for any form of statistical inference for joint distributions.
comments.author: sguha@mozilla.com
comments.creator: sguha@mozilla.com

Is this on the glean roadmap, perchance?
comments.raw_text: Is this on the glean roadmap, perchance?
comments.creator: chutten@mozilla.com
comments.author: chutten@mozilla.com

comments.raw_text:
(In reply to Chris H-C :chutten from comment #8)
> Is this on the glean roadmap, perchance?

We discussed joint ("grouped") metrics in the context of glean. They are not *yet* on the roadmap, but they *can* be if we'd have a concrete consumer for that :) After Fenix, though!
